title: Who will win the 2021 presidential election in Peru?
possible_answers: A candidate from Acción Popular (Popular Action)
A candidate from Alianza para el Progreso (Alliance for Progress)
A candidate from Fuerza Popular (Popular Force)
A candidate from Partido Morado (Purple Party)
There will not be a presidential election in Peru before 1 October 2021
preds: It’s virtually all done now. No path for Keiko Fujimori, other than claiming “the election was rigged.” The crowd odds of only .62 for Pedro Castillo are crazy at this point: https://twitter.com/ronaldcrossperu/status/1402466671793684480?s=21
https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2021/06/07/a-hard-left-candidate-has-a-slim-lead-in-perus-presidential-election Castillo 50,000 votes ahead with 6% of votes left for counting.

As is being said by some experts, the close vote count will lead to further instability and ungovernability and violence while the inevitable recount(s) will be challened, rechallenged, and by October (when the close of this problem ends) I suspect some things will come up and Keiko will be declared the winner.
Looking like Castillo now with the uncounted rural votes

Fujimori has a slight lead but Castillo is closing in and it sounds like most of the votes left are from rural areas where Castillo is favored. Predictit is heavily favoring Castillo, I assume they think the votes left to be counted will tip it in his favor. https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/7145/Who-will-win-the-2021-Peruvian-presidential-election https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/7225/What-will-be-the-margin-in-the-Peruvian-presidential-runoff-election

https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/perus-castillo-falls-polls-suggesting-photo-finish-against-fujimori-2021-06-05/
If it's a photo finish, will they be taking it to the matte?

The second-round run-off for the Presidential elections in Peru has become a contest between Pedro Castillo (Peru Libre), a left -wing populist and Keiko Fujimori (Fuerza Popula), a conservative daughter of a disgraced former president (currently serving 25 years for death squad killings and corruption).
Fujimori herself has spent more than one year in pre-trial detention accused of reciving illegal campaign funds and heading a criminal organisation.
Covid has further impoverished the populace and given rise to the left-wing candidate. The establishment/elite in Peru are supporting Fujimori in fear of a Castillo presidency.
The latest polls show a narrowing gap between the candidates with Castillo on 51.1% and Fujimori on 48.9% with another poll showing Castillo as dropping in support and Fujimori gaining. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/jun/03/peru-presidential-election-pedro-castillo-keiko-fujimori  https://www.as-coa.org/articles/poll-tracker-perus-2021-presidential-runoff  https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-05-30/peru-s-latest-polls-show-tight-presidential-race-ahead-of-debate  https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2021/06/03/peru-election-fujimori-castillo/  https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2021-05-30/peru-election-race-tightens-a-week-before-polarized-vote

Recent polls tightened a lot and Fujimori appears to be on the increase.  It's a little way back but just under half of the votes in the first round were cast for centre right candidates who are I imagine likely to break for Fujimori, so on that basis we are also looking at a very close result. Also we have to bear in mind the earlier polls were way off the mark so there has to be a lot of error involved.  I'm therefore only very weakly estimating a win for Fujimori based on some apparent  upward momentum.
Latest FT coverage reports experts saying capital is flowing out of Peru at an alarming rate due to fear of "communist"  leader...

New polls show both Fujimori's and Castillo's numbers have risen. Looking like it could go either way, as the difference is within the margin of error (https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2021-05-30/peru-election-race-tightens-a-week-before-polarized-vote).

Adjusting based on news of recent events creating bad publicity for Castillo, newest poll shows them neck-in-neck. Giving slightly more probability for Fujimori since I sense she has a little more momentum right now. Source: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-05-28/castillo-s-lead-narrows-in-peruvian-vote-simulation-for-runoff

Latest poll says Castillo is gaining over Fujimori (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-05-21/castillo-halts-fujimori-s-advance-in-latest-peru-runoff-poll). Still a toss-up with undecided voters, but given that both candidates are at the extreme ends of the political spectrum I'm assuming a 50-50 split.

It's amazing how consistently at least 15% of the electorate have either no idea whom to give their vote or intend to leave their ballot blank.
This speaks for Pedro Castillo not being very reknowned among the people of Peru, the political class being disrespected in general for their lack of honesty, loss of reputation or management of public interest, or a great deal of resignation. However, it could well mean that undecided will finally be aiming at a major change and are willing to offer the underdog with little history in office an opportunity.
Narrowing, looks like Fujimori is catching up in the latest polls.

Neck and neck in the polls, with a lot of undecideds: https://encuestas.com.pe/encuesta-2da-vuelta-cit-11-mayo-2021/  There's also been a bit of a Keiko surge, so that has to be meaningful. Probably a slight advantage for her at this point?
Polling looks like it's narrowing a bit.

https://www.ipsos.com/sites/default/files/ct/news/documents/2021-04/6980121INF_V1_21Abr21.pdf
Looks like voters are equal on why voting for each candidate on first place, agree with views.  But very different for other reasons.
Looking at the results of how strongly people would vote for each candidate it looks like a significant proportion of people are strongly against Keiko Fujimori and there are more definites for Pedro Castillo.  If there are so many strongly against Fujimori this will make it hard for her to get the number needed, although it looks like a lot of people won’t vote so it may depend on who turns out.  Plenty of time for the new guy Castillo to make a mess of things and the familiar lite of Fujimori to feel safer, even if people don’t like her. Things may change, it doesn’t look great for Fujimori at the moment.

The name of Castillo's "party" is Peru Libre = änother party...  According to reports in LatAm MSM he is scheduled to debate Keiko in his hometown on Labor Day (tomorrow) but he is apparently too ill to do that.  Keiko wants the debate held in Lima on Sunday 2 May on prime time TV so all of Peru can watch it.  Link... https://en.mercopress.com/2021/04/30/peru-libre-candidate-pedro-castillo-hospitalized-with-respiratory-problems Reuters reports that Castillo is up and running again and El Comercio in Lima reports that Keiko will drive to Castillo's home town to participate in the debate. Here is the link... https://elcomercio.pe/elecciones-2021/debate-en-chota-keiko-fujimori-manana-me-dirigire-a-chota-he-aceptado-el-reto-de-debatir-y-espero-que-eso-ocurra-pedro-castillo-cajamarca-puna-elecciones-2021-segunda-vuelta-nndc-noticia/

The following link in Spanish from La Tercera in Santiago de Chile notes that Castillo is off the campaign trail for now, admitted to a hospital in Lima due to "respiratory problems" ...  link https://www.latercera.com/mundo/noticia/candidato-presidencial-peruano-internado-de-urgencia-por-problemas-respiratorios/BBKDBRHWRNFIPCRBZCNIYROBBU/

I have doubts about the polling accuracy, but for now the polls do show Castillo with a huge lead. Note to self to look back at previous elections that went to a runoff and see what the polling looked like early on.

IEP poll shows Castillo has twice the support of Fujimori, and even if ALL the undecided voters voted for her, Castillo would still end up on top. Given the corruption in the country over the last few years and the charges against Fujimori’s father and herself, it’s unlikely the Peruvian public would have any appetite for a Fujimori presidency.  Source: https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/peru-socialist-stretches-lead-presidential-race-poll-shows-2021-04-25/
Castillo has a massive lead in the polls. I got this one wrong

I'm not going to put too much trust in the polls for the remainder of this question, the polls had some pretty big misses for the first vote. Polls might be more accurate with only two candidates though, and the only poll so far shows Castillo winning so switching to favor him slightly until we have more polling.
Polls were not overly helpful in predicting this market, and even though they are favouring "another candidate" by a decent margin now, I will handicap it slightly based on right vs left politics.

Well... Didn't see that coming!  Interesting to learn lessons from that, the opinion polls until very shortly before the first round election were way off.  Actually they fluctuated quite a bit so perhaps the lesson is to attribute less confidence to fluctuating polls?  For now I'm resetting forecast slightly favouring Castillo as, (er...) the one poll on the two candidates is favouring him, but will update after further analysis.  The key issue for me is who those who voted for others in the first round will move to. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Peruvian_general_election
Updating post first round. Will look to do something more in depth on the candidates through, but for now 2/3rds on plurality winner and 1/3rd on second

Castillo has wide geographic appeal and is a fresh face. Keiko will not make it.  Past results suggest otherwise, but Castillo looks both harmless and conduit of decisive change, while Keiko looks more dangerously self-assured than her father ever was, yet it is clear nothing consequential will change with her. Hence the large majority who believes that the system needs an overhaul will vote for Castillo; his unimpressive looks could well be a plus, counter-intuitively.

To me it seems like for Peruvians the aversion to leftism will trump their aversion to Keiko. Castillo seemed to have the far left lane mostly to himself, while Fujimori had competition, so it makes sense that he would win the plurality in the 1st round. It seems like of the 2/3rds of voters who voted for the field in round 1, the majority are likely to break for Fujimori. While I'm no expert on Peru and have no hope of becoming one, I have seen that it's commonly described as a conservative, even right-wing country. The one Peruvian native I know in person is quite conservative, though I acknowledge that's anecdotal.  So in the end, I'll put my money on Keiko here.
Going with the predictit odds for now until we see more polls. https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/7145/Who-will-win-the-2021-Peruvian-presidential-election

Pedro Castillo is the "another candidate" ... you can read about him in English Wikipedia here https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedro_Castillo
and in Wikipedia Spanish here https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedro_Castillo  His story as a rural socialist-populist cum reformer "has legs" as they say, but he is also anti-abortion and has been called the Evo Morales of Peru and his "victory" was praised by none other than the washed-up former Bolivian leader in international media link to piece in Brazilian portuguese Istoe here https://istoe.com.br/ex-presidente-da-bolivia-evo-morales-comemora-vitoria-da-esquerda-no-peru/ The center-right trend among the Adean nations after Sunday's presidential vote in Ecuador, and final nationwide gubernatorial elections in Bolivia, where Ivo's ruling MAS party got whupped big time- center-right (some would say "rightist" or "right wing") parties control 6 of the 9 state governments and Ivo's party just has 3, presents a problem for "the leftist professor" in Peru.  If you read Spanish this piece in today''s El Deber out of Bolivia's largest city (1.5 million) Santa Cruz, offers some clues.  https://eldeber.com.bo/edicion-impresa/en-el-mas-buscan-culpables-por-la-derrota-en-la-segunda-vuelta_227850 As a longtime observer of politics in Latin America, Castillo just doesn't pass the "smell test."  Promising to represent the poor, underrepresented, root out corruption, implement social programs from an empty cookie jar.  His "platform" of polarizing and creating conflict is somewhat similar to the strategy taken by Jair Bolsonaro when he was a candidate for the presidency in Brazil.  And we know what happened there.  

His candidacy sends up red flags among the extractive industries (mining) in Peru, since the nation is short on funds and if he wins he is likely to put the arm on them via taxes, other fees, unions demanding "fair wages", the wage issue could cause alliances with other leftist groups still hanging around from the old days when Keiko's father and his spy chief Vladimir Montesinos were the showrunners.  Keiko is the best of the worst.

For now left wing outsider Pedro Casillo, sometimes called the Evo Morales of Peru is the front runner.  Who emerges as the candidate to challenge him remains to be seen, lots of backstabbing, backroom dealing and fake news for the next six months.   Note that the results are provided in percentages of the vote, which, itself is a percentage of the -- not revealed-- total votes counted.  Narcos, other foreign influencers abound.  If you don't think the Albanian Mafia, N'drangheta, the Yakuzas and Triads, new generation Mexicans, just to name a few don't give a hoot, think twice.

Latest polls not looking as good for Lescano

The second round will polarize. The only chance for Accion Popular to win is if they make it to the second round with Fujimori. If other than Fujimori from the right makes it to the second round that person will win. There is strong opposition to the left in Peru. Only the rejection of Fujimori is greater than that.
The incumbent is from the Purple party, so that might give the party an advantage. The pandemic and the unstable political situation are both reasons why there might not be elections at all.

Candidate Rafael Lopez Aliaga of the Renovcion Popular Party is creating attention for himself claiming that the Biden Administration has offered Peru Covid Vaccine.  The foreign minister vehemently denies this, as this article in Spanish from El Comercio indicates.  https://elcomercio.pe/politica/gobierno/cancilleria-niega-haber-recibido-ofrecimiento-de-gobierno-de-joe-biden-para-vacunas-contra-el-covid-19-rafael-lopez-aliaga-nndc-noticia/

Yonhy Lescano has recently risen conserably in the polls, now seems almost certain to get into the run off and also seems to have broad support across the political spectrum including voters who identify as centre right, he also has the lowest 'anti' vote (those who avow they will not support the candidate) of the candidates.  I have put Keiko Fujimori down as her poll ratings have fallen and she is a polarising figure, unlikely to win against Lescano who has broader support.  Another candidate encompasses George Forsyth who is currently disqualified but could appeal, poll ratings have dropped considerably but it could simply be that respondents assume he won't be allowed to stand so he could have a big bounce if he is officially reinstated.  Others also encompasses Veronika Mendoza, and Rafael Lopez Aliaga whose poll numbers have risen but again us unlikely to command a majority in a run-off. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Peruvian_general_election

Slight adjustment, upon further research. The problem from the perspective of the other candidates is that Lescano beats everyone in the head-to-head questions. The far-right candidates have more voter enthusiasm, but there's no real ceiling on Lescano's votes, as a guy with high name recognition and a solid resume who basically takes the popular view on the contemporary issues. Lescano 60%

Latest poll, commissioned by Peru's newspaper of record: 
https://elcomercio.pe/elecciones-2021/encuesta-el-comercio-ipsos-la-disputa-por-el-segundo-lugar-y-los-nuevos-escenarios-noticia/ Lescano of Accion Popular sure looks like he's getting past round 1 to me, based on the polling and what I have read. Given that he should have a plurality, that should make him a slight favorite, so bumping him up to 55%. I don't understand the crowd odds that have him at only 15%. Looks like most likely 2nd round opponent right now is Keiko (Popular Force) who looks to me to actually be about 15%. I put the "Another candidate" field at 30%. Unless something changes in the upcoming polls, I currently put Cesar Acuna and Julio Guzman at essentially nil.

As the presidential campaigning gains momentum prosectutors and opponents in Peru want to send Keiko back to jail big time. She is experienced at squiriming out of such situations in the past. Link in Spanish here via Santiago de Chile's La Tercera... https://www.latercera.com/mundo/noticia/fiscal-pide-30-anos-de-carcel-para-keiko-fujimori-por-lavado-de-dinero/EQ2IAXMBCRDH7DR5TPEHMNRTNE/

-10 on popular force, Fujimori just charged with money laundering. https://www.reuters.com/article/peru-politics-idUSL1N2L92IO

An "other," Aliaga (the Bolsonaro of Peru, in his words) is tied for a solid 2nd place with Fujimori. They both pretty much have the same voters
Forsyth (also "another candidate") is also tied for third. Solid 4th is Mendoza. Good discussion here by some experts on the Peruvian election:
https://www.thedialogue.org/analysis/who-has-the-edge-ahead-of-perus-presidential-vote/
Analysts are universal in saying Lescano of Popular Action is a high probability to make the runoff.
Looks like Forsyth is back in: https://ksusentinel.com/2021/03/06/research-leader-former-goalkeeper-receives-green-light-to-run-for-president-in-peru-3-6-2021-world/

According to recent polls (taken from Wikipedia, https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elecciones_generales_de_Per%C3%BA_de_2021), the Popular Action Candidate has gained votes. Chances increases given his more centered position in the political spectrum respect to his more near rivals. Keep an eye on the final list of candidates, it could change this probabilities

As far as I can tell, the race is pretty much even between Veronika Mendoza (Together for Peru), Rafael Lopez Aliaga (Popular Renewal), Keiko Fujimori (Popular Force) and Yohny Lescano (Popular Action). It's hard to tell what the undecided voters will do, but Keiko Fujimori's father on trial is likely to reduce the chances of a Popular Force victory, and her poll numbers haven't been increasing as steeply as the others. Also, with George Forsyth out of the race, his voters are likely to go to other liberal reformist candidates, which Keiko is not. Yohny Lescano is in the lead so far, but the margin of error is too large and too many undecided voters to say he will win with any degree of certainty. In any case, the election is expected to head to a runoff, and the undecided voters could prove instrumental in determining the final election results. https://www.startribune.com/in-peru-sterilization-case-against-fujimori-goes-to-court/600029157/  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Peruvian_general_election#Opinion_polls https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2021-02-14/perus-presidential-election-likely-headed-for-second-round-poll-shows

Drilling down a bit, Keiko (who has lived around half of her life in US) remains president of the K Party. And her "ruling tree" is intact. The role her American-citizen husband plays in her political life is usually not a part of coverge in US or Hispanohablante media. As a conservative populist she is a dealmaker and the deals that need to be made are with the rapidly expanding "extreme right wing" as this excellent opinion piece in Spanish in El Comercio of Lima explains... https://elcomercio.pe/opinion/columnistas/elecciones-2021-nuestra-extrema-derecha-por-martin-tanaka-noticia/   The notion of leftish-socialist broad front coalition suffers from decades of internecine warfare and bickering.  A factor that is playing out again now in Brazil.  The political fallout from the Odebrecht scandals still can hurt certain candidates.  For those who are not aware, Odebrecht has changed its name to NOVONOR, but the media still call it Odebrecht in Peru, DomRep, Colombia, other nations where the scandals are still alive.  Keiko understands "the attention economy" better than most.
Upon further research, dropping the odds for Alliance for Progress and Purple Party

I don’t understand the crowd odds. Usually I do and I don’t like to second guess. Does it seem likely that George Forsyth will be allowed back in? It does seem like a weird technicality that disqualified him
Fight Club. “Nobody talks about fight club”

George Forsyth was leading in the polls, he has been disqualified but is apparently appealing so there is some chance that he will be successful and be reinstated.  I previously gave him about a 60% chance of victory, I couldn't find any precedent for successful appeals against disqualification but in the 2016 election a couple of significant candidates were disqualified, don't know if they appealed or not but if they did they were not successful.  Arbitrarily rated Forsyth's chance of successful appeal as 20% so have reduced 'other candidate' score' accordingly and increased Accion Popular and Fuerza Popular in line with this, moving slightly more towards FP as Keiko Fujimori's poll ratings seem to have rallied slightly since I last posted a forecast. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Peruvian_general_election
https://www.latinnews.com/component/k2/item/87396-peru-presidential-frontrunner-to-fight-disqualification.html

Forsyth has been disqualified, so I'm significantly dropping the "another candidate" category. The next best-polling party not listed here is Veronika Mendoza of Together for Peru, close to tied for third in latest polls. But there's still a lot of uncertainty and undecided voters, as well as 11% of voters still choosing Forsyth which will likely be distributed to others. So with that I'm favoring Popular Action and Popular Force right now based mostly on latest polling but also backed up by their stronger presence in parliament. All info and polling here, and Forsyth's wiki has info about him dropping out: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Peruvian_general_election Link to my google sheet with the polling organized and GJ categories and parliament seats listed, note this does not yet contain the last two polls: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1AVwUu_XrJCKJrmUntHuCzRg86XCAl6h8cu__YqBUubQ/edit?usp=sharing

There will be a second tour, and in this case, George Forsyth should win, in regard of the recent polls.
Guzmann - Morado, as well George Forsyth, is in a decline, Fujimori doesn't go anywhere, Lescano from Accion popular is in a rise.

With George Forsyth out of the picture, it's likely his voters will defect to other reformists. Yonhy Lescano (Popular Action) gained 4 points since Jan, as George Forsyth lost support, so it's possible he will benefit from Forsyth's misfortune and develop a lead. If no large changes in the current poll numbers occur, however, things will go to a runoff between Lescano and either Fujimori or Mendoza (of Together for Peru). This is why I'm still keeping some chance for Other.  https://www.bnamericas.com/en/news/peru-greenlights-16-presidential-candidates-for-april-elections
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-peru-election-poll/perus-presidential-election-likely-headed-for-second-round-poll-shows-idUSKBN2AE0OR
https://www.plenglish.com/index.php?o=rn&id=64485&SEO=neoliberal-candidate-leading-in-polls-in-peru-loses-support

+10% to Popular Action since people seem to be considering their candidate, Yohny Lescano, a viable alternative to George Forsyth, who is out of the running (https://www.bnamericas.com/en/news/peru-greenlights-16-presidential-candidates-for-april-elections, https://www.plenglish.com/index.php?o=rn&id=64485&SEO=neoliberal-candidate-leading-in-polls-in-peru-loses-support). Her poll numbers have ticked up 4 points since January, and if George Forsyth is blocked from running, his voters may defect to her, giving her a strong lead. The reformist ideology of her party could present an attractive contrast to the more centrist Partido Morado (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Popular_Action_(Peru)#Electoral_history, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purple_Party).

Adjusting up for Popular Action and Purple Party due to very surprising recent events (https://www.plenglish.com/index.php?o=rn&id=64485&SEO=neoliberal-candidate-leading-in-polls-in-peru-loses-support, https://www.bnamericas.com/en/news/peru-presidential-candidate-confident-justice-will-prevail-after-election-exclusion). Popular Action, Purple Party, and Nationalist Party are all practically tied. Particularly notable increase in Popular Action candidate Yonhy Lescano's poll numbers (https://www.plenglish.com/index.php?o=rn&id=64485&SEO=neoliberal-candidate-leading-in-polls-in-peru-loses-support), so I'm giving her majority of points that Another Candidate loses from this news. Another Candidate is still a strong possibility because the Nationalist Party and Together for Peru are still in the running, and National Victory could also get Forsyth back in the running with an appeal to JNE (https://www.bnamericas.com/en/news/peru-presidential-candidate-confident-justice-will-prevail-after-election-exclusion). However, even if Forsyth is reentered, it is likely his reputation will be tarnished by the scandal.

I updated my table based on the latest polls in wikipedia, and based on the last five polls it's looking like another candidate is a strong possibility. That said I don't understand the confidence here. For one around 20% of voters appear to be undecided, and another 25% did not answer. So there's a lot of potential votes out there that we can't be sure about. For another, even if we assume that George Forsyth of National Restoration is guaranteed to go to the runoff, his competitor seems very much up in the air. The next 6 best-polling parties range from 3.78% of those polled to 5.84% in the last five polls. I would imagine the margin of error on the poll encompasses that range. And 3 of the 6 are their own buckets outside the "another candidate" bucket, and the ones with their own buckets actually hold seats in parliament, which leads me to believe they're likely to be better recognized and may pull more of the undecided voters. Alternatively they could be more hated and pull fewer of the undecided voters, hard to say. Hard to say what will happen, but I think there's a very strong possibility that a candidate from one of the bigger parties makes it to the runoff, and if that happens it's very possible that the remainder of the voters back that candidate instead of Forsyth. And this isn't just a hypothetical, looking into what happened in the 2016 presidential election Fujimori won the first round with a strong 39.85% while her competitor Kuczynski had 21.05%, but in the runoff Kuczynski went on to win with 50.12% of the vote to Fujimori's 49.88%. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Peruvian_general_election#Main_presidential_candidates Link to google sheet with the polling and parliament breakdown: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1AVwUu_XrJCKJrmUntHuCzRg86XCAl6h8cu__YqBUubQ/edit?usp=sharing

Purple Party: 6.58%
Together for Peru: 5.63%
Popular Force: 5.25%

Alliance for Progress: 2% Popular Action have had 3/11 Presidents since democratic elections took place but only one was directly elected. Purple Party held the office most recently but as a result of the succession.  Two of the top candidates are from other parties not listed and one of them is the heavy favourite at the moment, only Partido Morado and Fuerza Popular have viable candidates it seems but as @MArran has pointed out Fuerza Popular's candidate is tainted by corruption. The apparent lack of a base for these parties is further indicative of another party being likely to win. Popular Action and Alliance for Progress won the most votes in the recent legislative election but with around 10 per cent of the vote that won't be enough for the Presidential election (and their candidates aren't doing well). The vote was hugely fractured with over a dozen parties within 5 per cent of each other which further highlights the lack of an established base for these political parties.  My estimates are based off current polling, recent legislative elections and the histories of candidates. At the moment 'another candidate' is the clear favourite.
it will be an independent candidate

With elections scheduled, public opposition to their postponement even from congressional incumbents (https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-peru-politics/head-of-perus-congress-assumes-presidency-vows-to-respect-election-timetable-idUKKBN27Q1XD), and Peru's coronavirus case rate likely to decrease further as Spring arrives and a vaccination campaign begins, it seems unlikely that there'll be no election before the 1st October. But a postponement/cancellation can't be ruled out in such a crisis, so a 5% chance seems reasonable.  In the case that an election happens, Peruvian political parties are extremely weak and representing an established party probably hinders candidates chances rather than helps them (https://www.americasquarterly.org/article/perus-problem-is-bigger-than-not-having-a-president/), so the candidates are probably more important. Taking them in turn, with info from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Peruvian_general_election:
-Acción Popular's candidate is Yonhy Lescano, who's polling in 5th or 6th place. Little-known former professor and congressman, suspended under sexual harassment allegations in 2019, who'll struggle to increase name recognition.
-Alianza para el Progreso's candidate is César Acuña, who's polling in 9th or 10th place. Former governor, who reached 3rd place in polling in 2016 and faced accusations of money laundering, vote buying, and plagiarism before being barred due to nomination irregularities. Being well-known but low-polling implies the scandals have hurt him, making his chances low.
-Fuerza Popular's candidate is Keiko Fujimori, who's polling in 3rd or 4th place. Reached the second round in 2011 and 2016, in part due to the support of her disgraced former-dictator father's base, but limited by his unpopularity and her 2018 arrest in the Odebrecht corruption case. Very widely known but 5-10 times less popular than in 2016, so unlikely to win.
-Partido Morado's candidate is Julio Guzmán, who's polling in 2nd or 3rd place. Centrist former economist and minister who reached second place in polling in 2016 before being barred, apparently due to his refusal to pay a bribe (https://larepublica.pe/politica/2020/09/02/la-red-de-cuellos-blancos-del-puerto-tambien-infiltro-el-jurado-nacional-de-elecciones-ministerio-publico-julio-guzman/). Not polling as well as in 2016, but a good fit for the anti-corruption mood.
Other significant candidates are:
-George Forsyth, who's polling in 1st place. Former international footballer and district mayor, without clear policies but with a clean image, despite domestic abuse allegations in 2019.
-Verónika Mendoza, who's polling between 2nd and 4th place. Centre-left former congresswoman, who reached third place in 2016. Not polling as well as in 2016, but a strong candidate.
-Hernando de Soto, who's polling between 2nd and 9th place. Neoliberal economist and former Fujimori advisor, who's not a great fit for the anti-establishment mood. Overall, Guzmán's probably the strongest candidate and the closest equivalent to the popular deposed president Vizcarra, followed by Mendoza, but Forsyth might benefit from name recognition and anti-establishment sentiment. Polling has too many 'don't know' and 'other' responses for a model, even without considering the second round, so probabilities are guesses.

With the legislators impeaching a popular president and installing an unpopular one who lasted a matter of days, the country must be totally disillusioned with its political class with calls for constitutional reform. 
32% of people in a December 2020 survey said they would not support any candidate. The polls are showing George Forsyth to be leading with just 18% support while the purple party candidate (same as Sagasti) is only at 8%.

National Restoration (George Forsyth) has the most support. The big question is how much consolidation could happen by election time. It's hard to say what parties might drop out and put their support behind another candidate, or if that will even happen at all. Hard to be confident on any of these. Some of the parties with little support have larger representation in parliament, so it's difficult to determine if the polls are missing some support for these candidates.
